Data: Desmoid-type fibromatosis, aggressive, benign, monoclonal fibroblast proliferation. Size: 18 × 10 × 6.4 cm.
Located in the left anterolateral abdominal wall, locally aggressive, high risk of local recurrence.
Previous exeresis of abdominal neoplasm, appendectomy, two cesarean sections, and a voluntary pregnancy termination.
Initially treated with a small prosthetic mesh; recurrence in 2014 treated with tamoxifen and chemotherapy.
MRI used for tumor staging showing significant progression.
Case discussed in Multidisciplinary Sarcoma Meeting leading to decision for surgical treatment.
Large excision of tumor and affected muscles with reconstruction using a biological matrix (Egis®).
Use of non-cross-linked porcine dermal matrix Egis®, hydrated and sutured to the fascia and abdominal wall muscles.
Uncomplicated postoperative course, discharged on the 8th day.
No evidence of recurrence or incisional hernia at 12 months, successful integration of the biological matrix with tissues.
Informed consent obtained, study protocol approved complying with Helsinki guidelines.
No funding for paper preparation, no conflicts of interest declared.
Desmoid Fibromatosis of the Abdominal Wall, surgical resection and reconstruction with biological matrix Egis®
Previous exeresis of a neoplasm in the epigastric region, reinforced with prosthetic mesh
Appendectomy, two cesarean births, voluntary pregnancy termination
Desmoid-type fibromatosis
Left anterolateral abdominal wall
Initial size not specified; Recurrent size 18 × 10 × 6.4 cm; Aggressive growth noted in MRI
Tamoxifen therapy for 1 year, followed by 3 months of neoadjuvant chemotherapy
Decision for surgical resection made after multidisciplinary discussions
Large excision of the tumor with negative margins; involved the abdominal rectus muscle and parts of oblique and transverse muscles
Utilized Egis® non-cross-linked porcine dermal matrix, hydrated and sutured to the fascia and abdominal wall muscles
Uncomplicated, discharged on the 8th postoperative day
No recurrence of the tumor or incisional hernia at 12 months post-operation; successful integration of the biological matrix

Desmoid tumor (DT) is a benign monoclonal fibroblast proliferation, rare with 2-5 cases per million annually in Europe. It's locally aggressive and recurrent, with high risk of local recurrence despite surgical resection.
Risk factors include surgical interventions, pregnancy, and hormonal treatment. The median diagnosis age is 35, frequently affecting women, particularly on the abdominal wall.
A 37-year-old woman with a history of DT, previously excised and reinforced with mesh. Later treatments included tamoxifen and chemotherapy due to disease progression.
MRI in 2015 showed progression; surgical resection was decided upon by a multidisciplinary team.
The tumor and affected muscles were excised en bloc, followed by reconstruction using a biological matrix (Egis®), secured to the fascia and abdominal wall muscles.
Egis® (Decomed), a not cross-linked porcine dermal matrix, chosen for favorable properties such as resistance to infection and compatibility with patient tissue.
Uncomplicated recovery, patient discharged on the 8th day.
No recurrence or hernia noted at 12 months, MRI confirmed successful integration of the biological matrix with surrounding tissues.
Wide excision necessary for local control; biological matrices preferred over synthetic meshes due to lower risk of complications like adhesion and infection.
Emphasizes the necessity of wide disease-free margins and potential benefits of ADMs over synthetic meshes in abdominal reconstructions.
